But we're focused on a very special kind of rig category, which we call a 2-rig purely for the sake of brevity. These show up in representation theory, K-theory and other branches of math with a strong 'linear algebra' flavor. For example the category of finite-dimensional vector spaces is a 2-rig, but not the category of finite sets.

We wrote one paper about this:

https://arxiv.org/abs/2106.00190

I conjectured that the groupoid of finite sets and bijections is the 'weakly initial' rig category. In other words, it maps to every other rig category in a way that's unique up to natural isomorphism:

https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/rig+category

This would give yet another reason why finite sets and thus natural numbers are important.

My conjecture was proved in 2004 by Josep Elgueta. The proof was complicated. In fact, it had a mistake! Elgueta fixed it in 2020:

https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.0868

(4/n)

In the early 1970s, Kelly and Laplaza formalized what's going on here, by introducing 'rig categories' (which they called ring categories). Their axioms relating ⊕ and ⊗ were complicated, because all the usual rig axioms hold only up to isomorphism, like

a ⊗ (b ⊕ c) ≅ a⊗b ⊕ a⊗c

and these isomorphisms need to make a bunch of diagrams commute. That is, a bunch of diagrams *do* commute in all the examples that matter, so if they didn't it would seem weird.

(3/n)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rig_category

title: Here’s how Washington weaponized America’s IT companies and why it backfired

last_post.content: We'd already used this term in passing - https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2015/12/16/this-is-the-real-reason-why-european-privacy-rules-challenge-the-u-s/ Our basic intuition was (a) that networks bound the global economy together, and (b) that they were increasingly being turned into tools of power coercion. So we started writing. Initially, we wanted to do a more public focused piece for one of the big international policy journals, to get the idea out while it was still fresh - but they didn't bite. So we started writing a more traditional academic article instead.

Political conditions & institutions—as much as economic gains—shape every step of the migration process

title: New AI classifier for indicating AI-written text

last_post.content:
OpenAI released a tool which purports to detect AI-generated text. At the highest end of detection, it labels text "possibly" or "likely" AI-generated. 21% of human-written text falls under "possibly" and 9% of "likely" does. That's 3 in 10 students being defamed and/or harmed.

Just like other providers of academic surveillance software, OpenAI states that their detector "should not be used as a primary decision-making tool".

It will be, though. And harm will follow.

https://openai.com/blog/new-ai-classifier-for-indicating-ai-written-text/

https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.01.31.526541v1

They do total codon mutation of a DNA packaging gene in AAV2, and find mutations that improve productivity. Interestingly, these translate to AAV5 and AAV9!
